text:
PDF has established itself as an
interchange format now.

Did people get it - straight away - as to
what it was for?

Was it like PostScript was - relatively a
howling, roaring, success from day one?

I mean people couldn't wait to buy
PostScript in 1985. I'm not kidding they

were pressing cheques into Steve Jobs' and
John Warnock's hands and saying: "How much? How much?  I want

that NOW and I want it quicker next year!"
It wasn't like that with PDF - it wasn't at all.

This was brought home to me in the most
amusing - but at the time - scary way in

I think was the mid-nineties. My
guess would be it would be round about

1996. I was visiting Adobe fairly
regularly doing lots of stuff with them

on PDF and so on. And on this particular
occasion San Francisco immigration gets

hold of my passport and said:  "Purpose of
visit, Sir ?"

"Business or pleasure?"  I said:  "Well it's
business". "Oh! which company are you visiting?"

I said: "Oh! it's Adobe. They're in San Jose now".
"Ah! that's interesting, Sir, and what work are you

you doing with them?" I think it's the
usual thing that we all get used to is:

"Are you an illegal immigrant; are you
actually working for Adobe?" or "Are they

paying you; are you an employee, Sir?". 
"No! no!  no! it's just that we are interested in

the same things; we're doing research and
I'm just here for a catch-up and various

meetings with people as to where we are
with our project". And he said; "But what

kind of work do you do with Adobe, Sir?"
and I said: "Well you may not have heard

of it but they do have a product - a
format if you like - called PDF, and you can

read it with a free thing called Acrobat
Reader". And his face froze and I thought "Oh! dear"

and he took his glasses off. He put them down and
he turned my passport over, put it to one side,
and said:

"Sir! that PDF!  What is it FOR?!"  And I just ... 
I'd heard similar things from other people, I

just grinned. I said: "Well, do you want the
five minute story or the one hour story?"

I'll try and keep it as brief as
I can. I said to him:  "Look, you know you

probably exchange documents with people
and you've been told - you've been told

you should use this route to PDF and use PDF
as your standard interchange format?" And he said:

"Yeah! Yeah! that's quite right. We can't
understand why we can't just send each

other Word files!"  And I said "Well, you'll
know some of the problems of sending each
other Word files. Everybody's

got a slightly different version and 
- oh! dear - some people are running it

on Macintosh and not on PC and it doesn't 
look the same ...?"   "Oh! tell me about it!" he said

And I said:" Well ... and then there's the
refuseniks who say: 'WordPerfect is a far better

and I absolutely refuse to use anything
from Microsoft' -- or whatever?!"

"Oh yeah! We got a few of those as well". So
I said: "Well the thing to remember is - it is

about document exchange. but it needs to
be, ideally, you  want a general solution

that's of high-quality that could serve
all sorts of other use cases. Just

consider newspapers they want something
which is accurate and will print out on

an enormous sheet of paper. But yet they want
to preview it at smaller sizes and they

want one document to fit a whole load of
sizes and resolutions and to move

seamlessly between them taking quality
all the time - that it doesn't start

breaking up - even if you inflate it to 
almost the size of a barn door. And I

said; "Newspapers really, really, value that
capability of it" And he said: "So, like,

they have a route to this PDF?" And I said:
"Yes, they've  got to have a route to PDF and
I said "The other people -

let me give you one more example", I said,
is that many of my colleagues think it's

just magic for output from a program
called AutoCAD, you know,

"computer-aided design" it could be used 
for architects drawings; it could be used for

electronics engineering circuit diagrams.
But the great thing for them is that

when you scale it up to a different size
it keeps the quality and by that I mean

that if it's drawn as a nice smooth
looking circle, at this kind of size, you

scale it up and the circle still looks
like a circle. It doesn't start breaking
up into dots.

It's a graphics model; it's a  sophisticated,
scalable, graphics model inside the thing.

And that's why engineers love it as well.
And at that stage a great grin came over his face
and he said: "Sir!"

-- puts glasses back on -- "Sir, thank you so
much for that!"
"Thank you!  thank you! ". He gives me my passport back:

"Welcome to the United States, Sir". So I went
away thinking "I'm not too surprised by

that - a lot of people really don't get it;
don't understand what it's for". And I

did think -- I don't think it was quite
on that trip, it might have been the next

year that I'd been involved with Adobe,
on and off, for many years but

particularly in early '93.  John Warnock and
his colleague Chuck Geschke chose us here at

Nottingham to be one of the first beta test
sites for PDF. And I think it was maybe

the year after my interaction with the
immigration official and I went to see

John and I said, first question was, I said:
"John.  PDF - how's it going?"

And he said: "David, it's a long, long, long,
uphill struggle!" And i said "Yeah, I can

tell it's not been kind of the overnight
success that PostScript was?" And he said:

"No, it isn't. And he said "If you want to
ask me how much I've spent already on PDF

the answer is $100 million. It dawned
on us straight away, that  if we want people to

adopt PDF you absolutely have to give
them a Reader and it must be free.

The moment you start charging for it
people will just refuse and will not use

your format. So he said "We've had to live
with that" but he said "I'll say it again

- we are sure we are right!". So I went then
downstairs to talk to my colleague, Ken, who I

think was my liaison person at the time
and told him this story. He said: "David,

those of us on the technical side of things - we
know that John and Chuck are absolutely

right". "But" he said, "I have to tell you
that within this company there's jitters,

there's nerves,  because particularly
among the sales staff you see, they say
'We don't get any bonuses out of PDF!
People don't understand what it is,  y'know,

and all that. Please put me in charge
of Photoshop! I'll make loads and loads of

money and bonuses out of Photoshop. And I
said; "Yeah! it's understandable". And having

heard from friends at Adobe about how
being in charge of Photoshop was deemed to be
the real ....

I thought; "Well, you know, the measure of
PDF success is going to be when, if ever,

will its sales revenues overtake those
of Photoshop?" And the answer to that I

think it's in - I've got a book somewhere called 
'The Adobe Story' - I think it was April 2004

when finally PDF revenues
overtook those from Photoshop. And

in my visit, around about that time, with
great hilarity, the Photoshop mob as I

recall were on the lower floors of the
San Jose building around about four to
six, or something like that.

The PDF/Acrobat/PostScript people were
much higher up:  floors 11 and 12. The top

management, John and Chuck and so on, were up
at the top of the tower.  And I was told

when I got there that - to great hilarity -
the moment the sales results were

announced and PDF / Acrobat sales had
overtaken Photoshop, large quantities of

champagne were sent from floor 4 up to floor 
12, with ribbons and congratulations

cards, and the message was: "The pressure's on
you guys now -- have a nice day !"
